author: LECARRE

title: D300VS Effector for a Zesty Dual Nimble and Chimera

description.text:
An effector that can be used to mount a Dual Nimble to the Ultibots D300VS so you can use a Chimera/Cyclops hot end.

There are 2 versions.
One version that is built up with 2 parts. These parts can be printed using the FDM process. They are the parts named Part A and Part B
The second version is designed primarily to be printed using SLA or SLS. It will need a lot of support. It is the part named SLA.

As usual we have added the STEP files and now also the IGES files as some customers were asking for it.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

comments.text: How does this affect the build height on a D300VS / D300VS+? Looking at the engineering documents, it looks like this should have a bit more height on the VS as the VS+ (+15mm height). Will that cause a problem with the arm lengths? Would I need to move the endstops?
comments.author: kwisatzsawyer

comments.text:
Hi, end stops are only at the top right? So even if the hot end is taller or lower than the previous one, the end stops stay the same.
You will need to adjust the max print height in your config, yes.
In the Chimera case, it is lower than the regular V6 hot end. I don't know the config you are using now. Either way, you will need to do a height calibration.

author: jodyw

title: Tube mesh extrusion library for OpenSCAD

description.text:
This is a library for generating "tube-like" meshes that join a number of cross-sections. For instance, one could use this for a wing profile, or a sphere, or thread.

The cross-sections don't have to planar, nor do they have to have the same number of points, but self-intersection of the resulting tube is likely to be a problem.

There is some greedy optimization done to make triangles in the meshes be close to equilateral.

One of the cool things one can do with this is "morph" between two plane shapes. For instance, 

morphExtrude(ngonPoints(30,d=6), ngonPoints(2,d=4), height=10);

produces a wedge whose bottom is a circle of radius 3, and whose top is a line of length 4, while

morphExtrude([ [0,0], [20,0], [20,10], [0,10] ], [ [ 5,10 ] ], height=20 );

makes a pyramid with a rectangular base.

The main low-level API is the module

tubeMesh(sections,startCap=true,endCap=true,optimize=true)

which takes a vector of three-dimensional counterclockwise cross-sections, and generates a polyhedron. The optimize parameter controls triangle optimization.

There is also the higher-level module

morphExtrude(section1,section2,height=undef,numSlices=10,startCap=true,endCap=true,optimize=false,twist=0)

This has two modes of operation. If height is undefined, you feed it two three-dimensional sections, and it interpolates between them to generate numSlices layers. If height is defined, you feed it two two-dimensional sections, and interpolation between the two sections separated by the specified height is generated. The twist is mainly for fun.

If you want access to the points and faces behind tubeMesh(), call pointsAndFaces() with the same arguments. This returns a [points,faces] vector. In fact, tubeMesh() is equivalent to calling polyhedron() with the output of pointsAndFaces().

As a demo, there is a cone() module and a mySphere() module. The latter has the same parameters as the built-in sphere() primitive, but it uses a golden-angle spiral to generate a sphere whose triangles are more uniformly sized than those from the built-in module.

There are also some useful utility functions:

  • ngonPoints(n=4,r=10,d=undef,rotate=0,z=undef): generate the points of a regular n-gon; 2D unless z is specified
  • starPoints(n=10,r1=5,r2=10,rotate=0,z=undef): generate the points of a star; 2D unless z is specified
  • roundedSquarePoints(size=[10,10],radius=2,z=undef): generate the points of a rounded square; 2D unless z is specified
  • sectionZ(section,z): takes a list of 2D points and add a z-coordinate to them all
  • shiftSection(section,delta): adds delta to every point in the section list.

Updates:
November 21, 2017: Added roundedSquarePoints(), sectionZ() and shiftSection().
September 17, 2017: Added tubeMesh() module for convenience.

title: CPK molecular model polymer clay jig

description.text:
Here's a jig to allow you to cut out consistent amounts of polymer clay to make molecular models at 50% of the CPK scale (1 Angstrom now 6.25mm)

The material used should be 3mm thick and glued in 2 layers, so that a rolling pin over the top will leave exactly 6mm thick bed of clay to be cut along the template markings.

More details here: https://tinkerings.org/2017/06/27/cpk-molecular-models-with-polymer-clay/

author: LieveW

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3FmdKlI2dz0

This is a scaled up version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22051. I had to split this in two stl files in order to print on the ultimaker. Some folks requested I upload the 2 stls for them to try out. So here it is...
  • Hitesh
    • Original file by Pranav Panchal, downloaded from GrabCAD: grabcad.com/library/eiffel-tower

6/8 Edit: I have uploaded the non split version as well - EiffelTowerTALL.stl - for people that want to download the uncut version to play around with..
  • Download STL files (eiffel1.stl, eiffel2.stl)
  • Slice
  • Print (Its quite a hard print - took about 20 hours)
  • Glue Eiffel2.stl on top of Eiffel1.stl.
    • I sliced using Cura (https://github.com/daid/Cura/wiki). One thing to note is that the slicer did not catch the vertical parts of the railings (as shown in the image with black arrow) , so the horizontal part was sort of hanging in air (As seen in the image of print on car).. but it was just 4-5 layers, so i did not care.. Just removed those strings later.. I believe if you play around with Cura settings or other slicer settings like nozzle size, you can even get the vertical railings to print..

remixed_from.author: tahustvedt
remixed_from.title: Bearing blocks for standard 8mm linear bearings (Wanhao duplicator i3).

title: Linear bearing blocks (8mm) for brass bushings (Anet A8, A6 and others)

description.text:
The x-bearings on my Anet A8 had way too much play and were quite noisy, so I decided to try some self-lubricating brass bushings instead (http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/n6mQbMZ ). The end result is dead quiet and much lighter than the original ones. There are no more bearing noise patterns on the printed objects.

The bushings I used have an outer diameter of 11mm and they can be press-fitted. If necessary, use a long M6 bolt and nut with two large washers and force the bushing into the block by slowly tightening the nut, but remember to protect the inside of the bushing from getting scratched by covering the bolt with tape or paper.

This file already has M4 mounting threads but depending on your print quality, you might want to clean them up with an M4 thread tap.

Note: Proper alignment is very critical with these bushings, otherwise they might get jammed very easily. My solution was to slightly enlarge the M4 screw openings (the ones used to mount the linear bearings) on the extruder bracket and y-carriage to 5mm and to first leave the mounting screws slightly loose, only tightening them (not too much!) after having checked that everything is moving freely. That way, the bushings will automatically find their ideal aligment.

I recommend to run your first few prints at reduced speed to allow the bushings to properly break-in.

EDIT 2.8.2017: Added smaller 10.0-10.5mm ID versions on request.
EDIT 23.7.2017: Added sizes 10.6-11.4mm ID due to requests for further sizes.

title: Washing Machine Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Recommend printing orientation on the side, tube facing upward away from the build plate, with supports, like so: http://i.imgur.com/jF3DygD.png. This ensures the material strength of the print such that the highest stresses are not along the layer planes. FDM Printing is an anisotropic process.

Fasteners are:

  • QTY 10 #6-32 press-insert nuts for plastic (McMaster 92395A113 or similar) (Assembly tip: Assemble it to the screw first, and keep threading the screw until the nut presses fully into the plastic. Keeps the brass tab from bending in the wrong direction.)
  • QTY 2 #6-32 x 3/4" SS hex-head screws (McMaster 92185A151 or similar)
  • QTY 8 #6-32 x 7/16" SS hex-head screws (McMaster 92185a163 or similar)

No

No

Notes:

Based to use US Nickel. Set build plate a little extra tight, this will help hold the slightly protruding nickel in well.

Pressing Nickel Notes

Press in bearing first as the 4 nickels will be slightly thicker than the bearing. Press the nickels in from the top in toward the first layer; try to press the last nickel in flush with the top layer, the first nickel will protrude slightly past the fist layer but will be held extra tight due to the first layers "squish." I used a socket slightly with an ID slightly larger than the diameter of the nickel on the first layer to finish the last nickels full insertion.
Lisam 210 anti vibration reinforcement

title: ERSA Tip & Tweezers Holder Stand w/Tools Slot for I-TOOL and CHIP TOOL VARIO
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model was built from scrath and adapted to work with ERSA i-tool and chip tool tips.
It can be stacked on top of a I-CON 1 or 2 using rubber pads and some 3M as i did.

I got inspiration from the great design "Solder and accessories stand"
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1587230

Giving my needs i have removed the solder wire stand, increase the size and number of slots for tools and adapted from ERSA tips, still it should work with other brands and easy modified for other brands

I-Tool Tips will snap fit the slot, but i'm using cooper bars to easy take or put the tips in place. Also cooper bars will allow you to use other brands.

If you print this for other brands please tell us to add to compability list

Features

  • 1 x Vacuum Desolder Slot
  • 18 x Tweezers Slots
  • 2 x Tweezers Like Slots for other tools
  • 24 x Tip Slots With Hole or snap fit

Tips Compability List:

  1. ERSA I-TOOL (Series 102 for i-Tool soldering irons)
  2. ERSA CHIP TOOL VARIO (Serie 462)
  3. JBC C105 Cartridges

Timelapse: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lH6DaYdjN0Q

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35um

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Silver PETG
Honeycrumb infill

Fit Cooper bars into holes
  1. Buy "3N548 - Soldering tip holder sleeve for 0A50 and 0A52 (3mm)" from ERSA
    • Alternatively buy a long cooper 3mm bar and cut it at your needs, after solder a wire into bar to make a ring.
  2. Place the bar into hole, use a hammer to push it down if needed

NOTE: I could have print the vertical bar into place, still this will limit the use of stand and also not good to place hot tips.

Fit bar into holes Alternatively snap tips into slot without bars Fit bar into holes Populate the stand Stack stand into ERSA I-CON

1.Buy or get 3M rubber feet, ensure that height is long enough to compensate ERSA curvy design.

  1. Place 1 feet at each ERSA upper corner
  2. Place 3M tape at top of the rubber feets
  3. Align and place the stand (With care, so you can remove if misaligned)
  4. If all ok push it down to glue it better

title: Ricoh Theta SC Butterfly Case (Arca compatible)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is used to protect the 2 lenses on the Ricoh Theta SC.
It can be deployed quickly and the 2 covers are used as a grip to hold the Theta SC.
When opened, the ends of the covers can be clamped in an Arca-swiss compatible ballhead.

A video clip of the case.
https://youtu.be/JFEMPIlKMq4

Hardware required:

  1. Brass Chicago Screw: Dia 4.5mm x L25 Qty x2 sets
  2. Rare Earth Neodymium Magnet Dia 5 x 5mm Qty x4 pcs
  3. Bolt 1/4"-20 x1/2" Qty x1 pc
  4. Countersunk Screws M3 x 12mm Qty x4 (not shown in exploded view.)
  5. Recycled bicycle inner tube (need a small piece to fit between "theta_BF_Top" and Ricoh Theta SC base.

Things to print:

  1. theta_BF_BaseV2.3 x01
  2. theta_BF_Top x01
  3. theta_BF_Dial x01
  4. theta_BF_CoverV1.7 x02

Things to note:

  1. Countersunk Screws M3 x 12mm are used to secure the "theta_BF_Top" to "theta_BF_BaseV2.3"
  2. Apply Loctite to the Chicago Screw threads.
  3. For "theta_BF_BaseV2.3" and the "theta_BF_CoverV1.7" need to use needle file to clean up the holes for the Chicago Screws.
  4. Use UHU Hart glue to glue the Rare Earth Magnets (http://www.uhu.com/en/products/model-building-adhesives/detail/uhu-hart-1.html?step=84&cHash=3256736a01e02c7f72c8319c9e3d707b)
  5. Ensure the Rare Earth Magnets are inserted in the right directions.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is just a little trivial twisty puzzle for all collectors and people who would like to claim that they managed to solve a "Rubik's cube". Concerning the solving aspect this is not a challenge at all and can be given to small children (if the risk of swallowing the piece can be prevented!). For everybody else this is just a small funny object to play around with. For that manner I designed it very small (15mm x 15mm x 45mm) so that it fits in every pocket. It can be used as a kind of fidget toy as it is just relaxing to turn the 3 pieces around.

If you want to make one yourself, all you have to do is print the file. This is a print-in-place design and should be functional without an assembly or any further work to do after the print.

If the puzzle doesn't turn right of the printer, please try to split the cubes apart carefully using a knife or something similar. If that doesn't work either try to print it in a higher resolution or at lower speed.

In order to make it a "proper" puzzle, cut some stickers out of paper, venyl or photo-paper. I used 10mm*10mm stickers but am sure that 12mm ones could even look better on this puzzle.

As this is something that can be printed in about 30 minutes, I hope some of you will try it out. If you have any questions, just ask me in the comments section. If not, just have fun with this little project.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

It is important that you place the puzzle so that the 1x1x3 face is sitting on the build plate. This object can't be printed standing on a single cube!

author: LECARRE

print_settings.Notes:: wobbuffet!

title: Hypercube Evolution X-carriage - 10mm x 16mm sleeve bearings

description.text:
!!WORK IN PROGRESS!!

This is a slightly modified version of the X-carriage for the HyperCube Evolution by SCOTT_3D. Since LM10UU simply won't fit inside the carriage without modifying the center-to-center distance on the original bearings, and the entire rest of the printer really wants 10mm rods, I've bored out the bearing channels to 16mm, which allows you to use 10mm ID x 16mm OD PTFE or UHMW sleeve bushings from McMaster-Carr.

PTFE/UHMW sleeve bearings are best used for softer rod materials like aluminum or carbon fiber tubes, which are much lighter and plenty strong, but will get chewed right up by normal LM8UU or LM10UU with hardened steel bearing balls.
Either bearing material will function better if lightly lubricated. Grease or oil may attract dust and grit, which over time will wear out the inside of the sleeve bearings and make the X-carriage not be properly constrained; however the sleeve bearings are cheap and quickly replaceable. Otherwise, a dry lubricant such as graphite powder may be desirable; the downsides to this are that graphite makes a horrendous mess and needs to be refreshed fairly often. My chosen method of lubrication was a bottle of SuperLube silicone/PTFE lubricant.

The best way I've found to apply the grease is to stick a glob of it around the rods at one end, then use the assembled carriage with all 4 bearings installed to slide over both tubes end-to-end repeatedly, to ensure an even application of grease. This should embed a small amount of grease both in the surface of the rod and the inner surface of the PTFE sleeves (which are made of PTFE anyways). Move the whole thing to one end and use a shop towel or something to wipe the excess off the entire surface of the tubes, as well as the ends of the bearings.

If the bearings are still a little stiff after all of this, take the bearings off and use them one at a time, on each rod, to figure out whether it's an issue with both pairs of bearings and rods, or just two bearings on one rod, like mine was. Use the small sanding wheel on a dremel to GENTLY hollow out the inside of the PTFE sleeve. You're going to be taking out just a tiny bit of material with each pass. Go slow, and test the fit with each bit of sanding. When you're done, use a paper towel rolled up to clean out the inside of the sleeve bearings, and re-do the grease steps above. At the end the carriage should just barely not be able to move under its own weight without the extruder installed, which leaves it tight enough to not wiggle but loose enough to not be terribly sticky during motion.

The center-to-center distance is unchanged, so the outermost wall might be a little thinner than would otherwise be desired but I've yet to fix that.
The rest of the model is unchanged.

!!WORK IN PROGRESS!!
Additional parts required:
4x McMaster-Carr 10mm ID x 16mm OD sleeve bearings (recommended PTFE or UHMW):
PTFE Sleeve: https://www.mcmaster.com/#2685T13
UHMW-PE Sleeve: https://www.mcmaster.com/#6657K13

Printer:

Prusa i3 hacktogether

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Originally 0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

wobbuffet!

comments.text: Those of us looking into building a Hypercube Evolution want to optimize the X-axis linear motion solution.  I wanted to make the Igus Drylin/Anodized aluminum rod solution my design choice, but when Scott3D had problems with his, I started looking for alternatives.  I like your solution for cost, weight, and chances for success.  Do you have any updates on whether you have had more problems to solve?  How did you choose between PTFE and UHMW sleeves?
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: Y-axis is just 10mm steel rods on LM10UU, using the regular hypercube evo parts. Since very little of that is moving mass, I just left it alone - later on I might look into Drylin bushings for noise and (slight) mass reduction.
comments.author: mlefevre

comments.text: it would be nice if the rod holder at the end had a removable clamp half shell that held the rod so that the whole thing did not have to be disassembled.    A simple 2 screw half shell clamp system.  or even better one side of the half shell clamp hinged and just one screw, maybe even a finger screw
comments.author: warham

comments.text: Ideally, on the hypercube evo, the X-carriage shouldn't actually be getting removed hardly ever to begin with. That, I think, was the point of having the somewhat modular design for the hotend attachment block, so you can quickly swap between them without needing any real disassembly.
comments.author: warham

comments.text: Thanks for doing this.  I've been waiting for a bearing and carriage combination that works for my cf tubes.  Just ordered the ptfe bearings from your link.  Please let us know if it works without additional reinforcement on the outer wall.  Thanks again.
comments.author: trevor185

comments.text:
Hey so I did a little fiddling with it to adjust the part, I've got a finished print with some spacers and whatnot. The bearings side-load into the carriage now, with solid spacers between them. Check the files list for a couple pictures of it assembled onto a pair of 10mm CF tubes. The end-cap bits that I've put on there also perform structurally in addition to keeping the bearings from popping out the ends, which did happen a handful of times with the earlier revisions. Let me know how it works for you!
I'm also putting some additional information in the description re: sleeve bearings and grease.

author: pauljs75

description.text:
This is a sample of my commercial model of the RS2027 formula 1 concept. You can find the full version here:

http://cults3d.com/es/artilugios/rs-2027-formula-1-concept-scale-model-esc-1-24

Follow me on Instagram: @guaro3D

The RS 2027 Vision formula one concept is the interpretation of how Renault sees the future of F1 in ten years, the car looks amazing.

This is a 3D model of the car made in 1/24 scale meant to be 3D printed, all the pieces are water tight and aligned to have an easy print process.

I have also included a complete solid 3D model of the hole car, in case you would like to divided in different ways or use another #D print method.

There are two types of Wheels, the ones with "no bearing" at the end of the file name are meant to be use without bearing given a static model, the other wheels use a 15x5x5 bearing to get movable wheels.

You will end up with a spectacular model of the RS 2027 perfect for your desktop or coffee table.

The model have been designed using Autodesk Fusion 360, a great tool.

title: Parametric Herringbone Gear Set for Huxley extruder #30DoC

description.text: This is a set of herringbone gears using the SCAD Script from Triffid Hunter, but with settings for smaller Huxley (eMaker / RepRap Pro) extruders that use M6 hobbed bolts and a Nema14 motor Enjoy perfect printing with Huxley. Made for Day 2 of 30 days of Creativity #30DoC - http://30daysofcreativity.com/ More on my blog - www.richrap.blogspot.com

They are a little tricky to fit onto the extruder body, take your time and get the motor aligned first, fix the motor tightly, then tighten the hobbed bolt onto the large gear, fit washers and bearing and slide both the large motor into the body and at the same time the smaller gear onto the motor shaft, tighten up the smaller gear to the motor shaft.

RailcoreII is a Core-XY based Reprap 3d printer designed by J. Steve White & Tony Akens. The initial idea to collaborate on a printer started in the #RepRap IRC channel, and centered on some common goals we both had in mind for a new printer design.

Core-XY motion.
All Linear rails for movement
Space & Cost Efficient, enclosable frame
Key components being printable, or able to be milled
Flexibility and Scalability in the design
A professional looking printer
Self Sourced and Easily customizable

Steve had previously built the “railcore”, the “alpha” version of this printer. We took what he’d learned from it, and began the design on the new printer. All design work was done in Fusion360.

As we progressed, we decided to “publish” this printer in an open, documented format for others to build as well.

The frame is designed to be 1515 aluminum extrusion. This was a space efficient choice, and it makes building the printer easy, as standard M3 hardware works like a T-Nut, fitting into the extrusion nicely. To add rigidity, we use melamine sides to stiffen the frame. (These can be cut out of any material you prefer, including plywood, acrylic, aluminum, etc). The total cost for the actual frame components (Extrusion, corner cubes, and sides) is roughly $100.

From there, some key design decisions were to make the build volume a 250mm cube. This kept the total printer size to what we considered reasonable. The design is easily expandable to 300mm cubed, and a new version at these dimesnions is forthcoming. Some notable aspects of the design: dual leadscrew Z-Axis with a belt drive between them, Stacked idlers duo-planar belt path, and lots of flexibility. The electronics in the design are the Duet (Wifi or Ethernet), 24v PSU, 0.9 degree steppers. We used an E3D v6 for the design, as it’s the most common hotend at this time. Support for other hotends will be forthcoming (needing only a different Y carriage). Semi-Direct drive or full bowden is supported.

A special thanks to Filastruder, Duet3d, E3D, SeeMeCNC, and 713Maker for supporting the project.

Link to the Bill of Materials For the 250^3 version:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KvlSNYHE20HYjQlURdH50Pn_V7t8TfuNNLnhcvI4Nos/edit?usp=sharing

Full CAD assembly in Fusion 360 for the 250^3 version: http://a360.co/2z30VXH

Link to the Assembly Guide for the 250^3 version:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1wBlwMw_H73dxT0H4OD7fWI7y6bFSvh7_BoBPMTmdTZs/edit?usp=sharing

There's an optional "ZL" build, to add 3 point automatic bed leveling: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2765693

BETA
The 300^3 version is now out in Beta! BOM And CAD Model are published, assembly guide will be out soon!

2/11/18 Update: Front & Back X carriages updated, Front and Back Stationary Idler Carriers updated.

comments.text: Could you explain some pro's (and con's ;-)  ) of the Railcore II if battled against a Hypercube Evo? They look pretty similar. Hypercubes uses 3030 extrusions though, and that sounds like it is better, but I understand your  comments earlier here about the sidepanels giving a lot of sturdiness instead.
comments.author: ConHen

comments.text: Enclosing the top will happen for sure.  The only real change is the idlers need moved out of the print volume, to minimize the # of holes needed in the top (just 4 for the belts, and a way to feed in the filament).  It just hasn't moved up on the priority scale yet.
comments.author: ConHen

comments.text: Thanks for your reply Kraegar. I am not trying to play you out with an opponent. I am just trying to find what's best suited to fit my wishes. I like however the way the steppermotors are mounted within the frame of the hypercube. But your design is very interesting because of the linear rail indeed, and having 713maker in your team is a pro for sure
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: Putting the steppers external was intentional. It kept the frame far more space efficient, so the printer is far smaller in footprint, and also keeps them external for when we put a top on it and fully enclose it, so they won't be in the hot internal area.
comments.author: ConHen

comments.text: I really like this design. Thanks for sharing your project!
comments.author: Zofoor

comments.text: Excellent - as you order, be sure to look at the item name / description to make sure the parts match up.  (We had an instance of a link in the BOM switching from the 5mm ID idlers)
comments.author: Zofoor

comments.text: Yeap, the BOM has been checked many times to confirm that all components are the correct ones, specially for me as I had to buy all from other shops that allows shipping to Italy.
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: Sounds like you've thought it out well!  I'd recommend HDPE if you can find it over plexiglass.  It can be cut on a CNC or lasercut, and won't crack like plexiglass can.  Though plexiglass should be fine.  If you can't get approximately 1/4" (6.35mm) then the printed stepper & idler mounts may need modified to suit.  I can assist with that if needed.
comments.author: Zofoor

comments.text:
Thanks for your advices!
I think I'll go with the plexiglas to keep the price reasonable low.
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: I'd have concerns about cracking with plexiglass on the sides, but if that happens it's always easily replaced!  Would love to see your progress.
comments.author: Zofoor

comments.text: Is the one Y-axis rail rigid enough to carry a direct extruder?
comments.author: Avamander

comments.text: Yes - we use a very short bit of PTFE between the extruder and the hotend, but it's essentially direct drive.  All of the weight is on the Y rail.
comments.author: Avamander

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: Sure!
comments.author: Avamander

comments.text: Great work! and I love the detail that you put into the manual.
comments.author: wildcardfox

comments.text: Thanks!  We have a couple guys building them now, and they're shaking out a few bugs here and there, but it should be all tidied up soon.
comments.author: wildcardfox

comments.text: I'll me building the gantry for my modified Duplicator 5S.
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text:
I’m looking at building my first printer. I already have a Maker Select v2.1, but wanted something bigger and quicker.
This printer looks almost exactly like what I want except for one thing. I would like a 300x300 print bed. How hard would it be to scale it up to allow a bigger bed?
comments.author: sse1990

comments.text: We're looking into redesigning at a 300mm^3 volume, it's definitely the most common question we get.  For the most part, things will scale just fine.  Scale up the extrusions, the linear rails, bed, heater, and sides, and you're mostly good to go.  Where the trouble is most likely to come in is spanning the Y axis unsupported over that distance as it is (just a linear rail holding the Y carriage).  We have various ideas around that, but nothing solid planned due to time constraints.  Possibly simply bolting on a 1515 to the back of the rail, modified X carriages, and a change in how the layer cooling is done would solve it, we just haven't laid it out yet.  The Z axis may need slightly bigger lead screws, but we're working on some other interesting ideas there as well.
comments.author: sse1990

comments.text: Kraegar these are freakin' nice photo's! What kind of multicolor technique did you use on the multicolor part? And how is the 300x300 coming along?
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: Thanks!  For the multi-color parts, I just did a pause and filament swap, them resume.  The RepRapFirmware macros for swapping filament made that easy.
comments.author: ConHen

comments.text: Thanks for the quick reply.  I'll keep an eye out for a bigger version.  I'll keep looking for something completed in the size I'm looking for and maybe once you have something released, I can build another one.
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: I posted the BOM & CAD model for the 300^3. The assembly guide will be coming along soon.
comments.author: sse1990

comments.text: Most impressive, sir!  Looking forward to working on this one.
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: Thanks! Come join us on FB or the forum for more updates and such!
comments.author: ranchrifle

comments.text:
I probably should, but sadly, at this point I do not book face....
However, I am following on the duet forum and the seemecnc forum!
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: I love the design, though I have a few questions, firstly, why did you not use double synchronized Z instead of the current solution? And secondly, why not 3030 extrusion instead of 2020?
comments.author: Avamander

comments.text: Using a single stepper with belt drive for the Z axis means we don't have to worry about the two steppers getting out of sync on power down, etc.  A single stepper has plenty of power to drive both leadscrews, so using two was completely unnecessary.  However, we are looking into a new duet feature of using three independent steppers for Z, to due true bed levelling.  We'll likely use three nema 14's for that.
comments.author: Avamander

comments.text: Interesting. Another small question have you considered creating variants of the 3d printed parts for 3030 extrusion that seems to be more commonly available and used (thus basically provide an upgrade path for people having Hypercube or some other printer based on 3030 extrusions)?
comments.author: kraegar

comments.text: We haven't - the 1515 is pretty integral to the design... and the total cost for Misumi pre-cut 1515 for the printer is only $32.  That's for the entire frame, including the Z Axis.  We're working on a scaled up version of the design, but it will continue to use 1515.
comments.author: Avamander

comments.text: Though I'd drop in a sample pic printed with RailCore II:
comments.author: jstevewhite

comments.text: Nice design, could you share more pictures ? Include one of the Z bed mount ;-) thanks
comments.author: jackantubis

comments.text: Thanks!  More pictures are coming! I took hundreds during my build, which is mostly complete now.  Just a little tidying up to do on the wires, and some other small details.  I'll try and get some pictures up ASAP.
comments.author: jackantubis

title: Light Blocking LCD Screen Cover for Original Prusa Mk2S

description.text: Since we don't have a lot of space the printer lives in the bedroom. I was astonished that my girlfriend's only complaint about it being there is that the screen puts off a lot of light at night. I designed this part to perfectly fit the cutout hole on the Original Prusa Mk2S LCD display, and added the Prusa name and a cute little handle to make it easier to get it in/out of the hole. Deutsch:
Ein grosser Radialventilator der von einem CPU-Lüfter(92mm) angetrieben wird. Um die Maximale Leistung aus dem Ventilator zu holen, sollte der CPU-Lüfter möglichst viel Ampere aufnehmen, je mehr desto besser, meiner zieht 0.54A.
Einzelteile:
Der Ventilator besteht aus mehreren Teilen.
• Dem Gehäuse, in welchem der 92mm Lüfter Platz findet.
• Dem Rotor, dieser wird auf den Lüfter gesteckt
• Dem Rohr. Dieses leitet den Luftstrom.
• Dem Lagerhalter, in diesem wird ein kleines Kugellager eingepresst und sichert somit die Lagerung gegenüber dem CPU-Lüfter.
• Dem Deckel, dieser verschliesst den ganzen Ventilator.
Zusammenbau:
Zuerst müssen alle Rotorblätter vom CPU-Lüfter entfernt werden und sauber mit einem Dremel oder ähnlichem verschliffen werden.
Danach den Durchmesser vom CPU-Lüfter dem Loch im Rotor angleichen. Ich habe den Lüfter wieder zusammengesetzt und im laufenden Betrieb mit Schleifpapier angepasst.
Jetzt können der Rotor vom CPU-Lüfter und der ausgedruckte Rotor zusammengeleimt werden.
Nun das ganze Packet in das Gehäuse kleben.
Danach das Kugellager in den Lagerhaltern einkleben. Und den kompletten Lagerhalten in den Rotor kleben. (Wenn ihr andere Kugellager habt schreibt ein Kommentar oder eine Nachricht und ich lade einen angepassten Lagerhalter für euch hoch)
Als Nächstes wird das Rohr auf das Gehäuse geklebt. ACHTUNG!! Auf Drehrichtung achten, sonst funktioniert der Ventilator am Ende nicht. Das Rohr muss länger sein wie der Rotor, sonst muss das Teil Deckel hoch verwendet werden.
Zum Schluss eine M3 x 20mm Senkkopfschraube mit Mutter in das Zentrum vom Deckel einschrauben, und das ganze nun aufs Rohr kleben.

English:
A large centrifugal fan driven by a CPU fan (92mm). To get the maximum power out of the fan, the CPU fan should take as much amps as possible, the more the better, my pulls 0.54A.
Individual parts:
The fan consists of several parts.
• The housing in which the 92mm fan is located.
• The rotor, which is placed on the fan
• The pipe. This directs the airflow.
• The bearing holder, in which a small ball bearing is pressed in and thus saves the bearing against the CPU fan.
• The lid closes the whole fan.
Assembly:
First of all, all rotor blades must be removed from the CPU fan and cleaned with a thimble or similar.
Then adjust the diameter of the CPU fan to the hole in the rotor. I put the fan together again and adjusted it with sandpaper during operation.
Now the rotor of the CPU fan and the printed rotor can be glued together.
Now stick the whole package into the housing.
Then glue the ball bearing in the bearing holder. And stick the complete bearing holder into the rotor. (If you have other ball bearings write a comment or message and I upload a customized bearing holder for you)
Next, the tube is glued to the housing. CAUTION!! Pay attention to the direction of rotation, otherwise the fan will not work at the end. The pipe must be longer than the rotor, otherwise the part lid high must be used.
Finally, screw an M3 x 20mm countersunk head screw with nut into the center of the cover, and then glue the whole to the pipe.

title: Wood to Trackmaster Train Track Adapter

description.text: Adapters to connect Thomas Trackmaster plastic track to Thomas- and Brio-compatible wooden train track. To render this shape, you will need tracklib.scad installed in the same directory as this file, or the dotscad/trains repository cloned in its entirety (which will include this file and tracklib.scad). This OpenSCAD library is part of the dotscad project, an open collection of modules and Things for 3d printing. Please check there for the latest versions of this and other related files.

I've been printing these with 3mm filament and .3mm layers, and the measurements should be good for both the trackmaster and wooden sides of the connectors.  
If something doesn't work for you, feel free to contact me and let me know what needs to be adjusted.

description.text: This is small food dish for my parakeet. It hooks to the inside of his cage and has a perch for him to sit on while he eats. I printed it in PLA on my Creality CR-10 using Cura set to the recommended settings for fine (0.2mm). I used 200 degrees Celsius for nozzle and 60 degrees Celsius for bed. It took about 6.5 hours to print and used about 20 grams of filament. I suggest using support as the perch is raised up on the dish. I used a brim for bed adhesion to blue painters tape rubbed with isopropyl alcohol. The print went very well and the dish works great. The support material was easy to remove. I did drill a small hole in the back of the dish to secure it to the cage with a twister seal for safety.

description.text: This is a remix of the servo bed created by Marten de Groot for robot Inmoov. I changed the servo bed to fit the smaller Tower Pro MG 90S servos. I really liked his idea for using smaller, lighter servos for the fingers and moving the wrist servo into the forearm. I was really concerned about the weight of the forearm with six standard servos installed. I am hoping the decreased weight will make my Inmoov's arm movement faster.

Notes:

I used PLA.

I modified the original file for the servo bed to fit Tower Pro MG 90S micro servos because that was what I had on hand. I also made a larger cut out for the wrist rotation standard servo wire. When I test fit the servo on the original, there was not adequate room for the wire to sit freely. I don't like pinched wires. I used Fusion 360. I am still a Novice so this is not a perfect remix. I did not make screw holes on both sides for the micro servos. I am going to just drill them out freehand.
I haven't had a chance to print and verify print ability. You will need to print supports (for the cab). As time permits I will update model to add more detail and test the print ability.

comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: The main problem is with the axial play on the steeper motor shaft. Worm gear during retraction is pushing the motor shaft in to the motor housing. Such behavior necessitates rapid wear of motor bearings. The best solution is to mount on the motor shaft the thrust bearing and reduce the axial clearance to minimum. Rest of the project is rather ok. I'm using 3mm filament and 60mm/s print speed.

remixed_from.title: Trim Ring & Cap for P6*6 Pinhole Camera

description.text:
I designed this as a way of adding a Neutral Density (ND) filter to the front of the P6*6 Pinhole camera.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:157844 Decreasing the amount of light exposing your film is a handy way of slowing down an exposure in very bright light. A "fast" pinhole exposure might be 1 or 2 seconds long. At these shutter speeds, the slight camera shake induced by opening and closing the shutter can blur the photograph. ND filters are made in whole "stops". Further, each stop halves the amount of light reaching the film. An ND2 is one stop, an ND4 is two stops, and an ND8 is three stops. An ND 8 filter allows you to make an exposure metered at 1 sec with a shutter duration of 8 seconds. Additionally, color filters may be employed for special effects. The included STL fits a nominally 52mm filter with an actual outside diameter of 54.50mm. Yours are probably different, but you can simply change the parameters in the script. I plan to port this to Customizer in the future. This parametric design can be adapted to other cameras, like a Holga, and any filter size.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

The OpenSCAD script employs some cleverness to ensure that the larger diameter (filter of lens barrel) is oriented upright, to eliminate overhangs. I find that my 3D printer doesn't print inside diameters as precisely as outside diameters. Before printing a batch of adapters, use the test_ring.scad file to determine the "fudge" variable in the adapter script. After all that monkeying around, I found that pressing the filter into the adapter stretched the ring a tiny bit and made the friction fit on the camera a bit loose. I got better results reducing my "lens_OD" measurement by 0.20 mm.
"We must be cautious" - Obi Wan Kenobi The script is well documented, but please post any questions you have in the comments! Printed in black ABS, 2 perimeters, 50% infill, 3 layers top and bottom. Sliced in Slic3r Ver 9x.

Continuing the development of the Menger sponge models, and encouraged by mathgrrl, this OpenSCAD script combines the cut and external support options and adds the ability to change the size and choose the order/level up to 3. Feb 6 update - added two more capabilities to the script:
  • a combination of cut and supported, to print a half-cube with the cut side facing up for folks with difficulty removing the finished object from their printbeds,
  • an option for an order zero cube - just a plain cube, no holes - so you can make a set showing the progression from cube to fractal.

The OpenSCAD script has the ability to generate Menger sponges of order/level 0, 1, 2 or 3 and to cut the model on the long diagonal or provide support structure so it can be printed standing on a corner without any internal support, or do both. The supports can be broken off easily after printing.  
Please note that although the scale isn't limited in Customizer, the support structure is only tested at relatively small sizes and may not work as well with really large prints; if nothing else it will certainly use too much plastic.  
It's also likely that OpenSCAD will produce models with some issues; I have found that order 2 and above need to be cleaned up before slicing. The posted STLs have been processed through Netfabb Cloud and should slice correctly.

author: CobaltGriffon

description.text:
I made some modifications to the original Seej penny catapult. -the bottom of the arms was bumping into the table while loading the catapult, so I trimmed a bit of the arm below the bottom elastic bracket. -I added an extra slot for the winding key and elastic further to the front of the catapult. This makes arms angle slightly steeper, which results in a slightly higer trajectory. -Because i didnt have the right elastic, power was a bit low, to counter that I added some more elastic at the top of the catapult. To hold the elastic, I made an indent in the catapult arm and made the crossbar protrude a bit on both sides. -Lastly, in case you grow tired of shooting pennies, I added a 'medieval' catapult arm. Shooting peanuts or perhaps a game of angry birds ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11438 ) anyone? The green catapult ha the original frame, with the modified penny arm.
The red canon is fully modified. That stack of 'amunition' are actually 10x10x10 calibration cubes. They come in handy now :)

For the original catapult only the stl files are provided. For the catapult arm, i hacked away at the original stl file in openscad. There was something wrong with the stl file for the side bracket, so i remodelled that. My openscad source files as well as zeng3's original stl files can be found in the zip file.

title: Water Bottle Drip Irrigation System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit 7/4/2017: Everyone here is super smart, so you probably already figured this out if you used it, but if you cut the tube in half (or cut it near-ish to the bottle), and place the valve where you cut, you can then run just the tube (which is much smaller than the valve) right up next to the plant's center, and even bury the bottom in soil/mulch!

I've updated the first two pictures to reflect the way it should probably look. I was too lazy to change/reshoot/remove the other ones. OR...was I just giving you an opportunity to see my version history, or even choose to go back to a simpler time, when we all knew a little less than we do now? Who knows?

If you secure the tube above and below the valve, you can even secure the valve, making it easier to turn on and off, maybe even one-handed? I think my next tweak will be a valve-holder. Spoiler-alert: it's probably going to look a heck of a lot like my light switch cover:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2295821

If you're in the U.S. and are into holidays, Happy Fourth of July! Otherwise, happy...well, I hope it's still the fourth of July wherever you are. ;) And if you're reading this on any other day? Celebrate anyway!

--End of Edits--

I like drinking alkaline water, and Trader Joe's has an inexpensive offering. I found the bottles piling up in the recycling bin (yay!) but then I asked myself: I wonder if I could reuse these bottles instead of throwing them in the recycling?

This project is an on-going response to that question.

To quote GlaDOS from the video game Portal:

Okay. Look. We both said a lot of things that you're going to regret. But I think we can put our differences behind us. For science. You monster.

And science, we will!

First, get a bottle that is very close to the bottle shown in the pictures. It should be a fairly standard 1.5L (50.7 fl oz - 1.59 qt) bottle, and you may be able to find this exact same bottle branded completely different somewhere else. I'm just going to go ahead and give you the important dimensions down in the "How to Assemble" directions below, but suffice it to say, Trader Joe's is awesome, and if you have these bottles, it'll work great!

The way it works is this: You've got these rain barrels (you DO have rain barrels saving the water from your roof, right?) which fill up with water. With this system, you can use some of the overflow/excess water and pour it directly into the top (which is technically the bottom of the bottle, but the bottom faces up in this system!), where it is mechanically filtered a little through the sieve, and the holes you will have drilled in the top (bottom?) of the bottle. There's some 1/4" OD (outer diameter) tubing, which you can get at most home improvement stores, and the end of the tube will have a valve.

Because water likes to go downhill, and enjoys taking a free gravity ride, try to place the water bottle as high up as you can, because pressure is caused by the vertical distance upward from your release point. A foot or two is fine. I just wanted to put my bottles just below the top of the fence line so they aren't visible from the other side. Sometimes water companies and homeowners' associations get weird about collecting rain water, and odd-looking contraptions affixed to your fences (respectively).

The reason why I like this system (for now...I mean, I'm fickle, and always trying to improve things!) is that each plant gets its own reservoir of water. When I did a test install near the house, it rained, but not much got in the bottle. That's probably a combination of minimal surface area (roofs are huge, and convert about 90% of the water, bottle-bottoms are much much smaller), and how close to the house I was. So now that I have a few of these installed, I will see how a decent rain works. For now, I will happily fill all of the bottles just before it rains, that way I'm reducing stored water in my water barrels, which often overfill, and also filling my irrigation system. True, it's a manual process (for now), but it's also a good way to save water, and maximize total water stored. Right now, I have eight plants that I want to water separately. That's about 12 liters in this system (remember that each plant gets its own water reservoir), for a total of three gallons. That's three gallons I'm removing from my rain barrel before it starts to rain, so that's three extra gallons I'm storing.

Once installed, it's as easy as turning on a little valve for a second, then turning it back off. Rinse and repeat with each valve, and your plants are all watered.

According to a gardening buddy of mine, it's super efficient to water plants "at the root" rather than from above, because there are waterborne illnesses, and also, water droplets can act as little mini magnifying glasses on your plants, and just like when kids fry ants with a magnifying glass on the sidewalk, these little mini water lenses can also do damage. Eek! Of course, you can avoid this by watering your plants early morning, or after the sun has gone down, but with this system, the water is placed right where it needs to go. Also, because you aren't really watering the rest of the bed, it may help reduce weeds!

Lastly, and this is a cool part. You can put a drop or two of your favorite fertilizer directly into the top, just before adding the water, and it will mix up automatically. Neat, eh?

Things of note:

  • You'll notice there are six holes in the top (bottom?) of the bottle, and one in the side. The one in the side close to the top is VERY IMPORTANT, because this allows air to escape as water replaces the air inside the bottle. Without this air hole, you'll get a lot of blorping and bubbling and sadness. Make sure you put a hole there!

  • After you've drilled the holes, try to use thick grit sandpaper to remove the larger chunks of plastic that will inevitably stick to the bottle. You don't want anything impeding the water flow.

  • Things should be relatively tight when you go to screw the bottle top back on, because now you have a filter washer inside. It's okay that you only get the bottle secured about halfway. Don't cross-thread, or break the threads. It's not a big deal if you have a lot of bottles, and need to try again because you broke one, but I'm thinking just be careful.

  • I'm sure there are plenty of ways to improve this system. For example, the white "collar" doesn't really do anything, but I installed it anyway over the tube. I think in a real installation, that collar would go around the tube, and fit into a hole. Then, things get expanded with the metal piece that goes into the tube.

  • This system, as designed, uses 1/4" OD (Outer Diameter) tubing and valves and the like. It's not a high-pressure system. If you have a leak or a blow-out, you lose a maximum of 1.5L of rain water. Not a big deal. Figure out what went wrong, and re-work it. Plus, let me know, because maybe there's something we can work into the design of the next revision? You should be able to get all of these items inexpensively at any home improvement store like Home Depot, Lowe's or whatever.

  • You could most certainly affix the valve to the wall, and then run a drip tube directly to the plant's stem, where it just peeks above the surface. That's fine. Just remember that a full-open valve, at a foot or two above, will be empty in just a minute or two, so watch it. You probably could turn it on, wait a few seconds, and then turn it back off, and conserve water. Happy plant, happy water bill!

  • If you have a different size bottle, please let me know in the comments. If you run into any issues, please create an I Made One here on Thingiverse and share pictures and comments with me. Not only do I love Makes, but I also love helping people to get these things to work.

  • You can use any color you'd like to print. PLA is pretty good, but may melt in the sun? Who knows? ABS might be better if you want to have something that lasts longer, perhaps more durable? But I like PLA, I had a lot of green PLA, and decided that green is great for the garden. It's your garden: so pick the color that makes you happy. You could literally have a rainbow wall of these things, if you wanted to, and that would be pretty fantastic. If you do make a rainbow wall, please share pictures with me!

I think that's about it. Here's a video of a raccoon playing the water harp:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Z_D2IfpF3g

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

None of these parts require rafts or supports, as long as you print them in the correct orientation, except for the sieve. That one got a little weird even WITH supports. I printed that sieve two or three times, and each time, after pulling away the supports, I got this weird pattern. It doesn't matter, and may actually help with filtration of smaller particulate matter? Who knows? Either way, the sieve probably requires a support, the other two don't, to the best of my knowledge.

How to Assemble

I've shared SO MANY PICTURES, so I'd say go through the pictures first, and decide if you want to read my directions. I promise you, I won't say anything funny, so if you want to just skip this, and follow my pictures, that's totally cool. I won't be offended. Or skip to the end, because I generally say something funny there, and that way you'll feel like you got everything, without having to read the boring directions that no one reads.

1) You need to wear safety goggles when working with a drill, because if a piece of plastic shoots up into your eye at high-speeds it can blind you. While that may make ME laugh at YOU because now you look like a bad-ass pirate (damnit, I said I wasn't going to be funny!), I'd recommend you avoid the lifelong eye-patch or glass-eye, and just wear the damned glasses. Seriously. Do it. Also, maybe don't shave for a day or two, and look a little scruffy. That helps with DIY I hear?

2) Do a dry run, placing the bottle above (always above - gravity) where you'll be watering. Water goes down. Bottle up, plant down. Easy? Cool. Place the bottle where you want to install it, and mark the bottom holder piece where you want it to go. Take the bottle out and screw the bottom holder piece into your surface, keeping it level. I didn't use a level, but I am fairly good at leveling things. Level (to the ground) is good when working with watery things. Water finds its level. The bottle should be level, and therefore, the system should be level. Once you have the bottom holder piece installed, slide the bottle back in and slide the middle piece (looks like a ring) over the top. I like to put it somewhere above the halfway mark, because that's where a bottle filled with water will "teeter." Maybe about 2/3 or 3/4 of the way up from the base? Again, mark where you'd like to place the middle support, remove the bottle, and screw the middle support in, making sure everything is level and parallel. The bottle should now slide into the system, and the top should be fairly level to the ground.

3) Now that the bottom and middle support structures are in-place, bring your bottle inside (or wherever you like to drill and do your work), and start working on the bottle.

4) If you're using the same bottle I'm using, there are five "bumps" on the bottom of the bottle, and a larger indentation in the center. Drill five 1/4 holes in between the bumps, and one larger hole in the center. This is VERY IMPORTANT: drill a hole in the SIDE of the bottle, as close to the top as you can, so that air can freely flow in and out of the bottle when water is added or removed from the bottle. After drilling these holes, roughly remove any excess plastic from the outside of the holes using rough grit sandpaper.

5) Drill a 1/4" hole in the top of the bottle cap. This is where your tube will go, so try to get it as close to 1/4" as you can. Don't keep reaming the hole with the drill, and make it too big, because my guess is, you'll create a hole and it'll leak. If that happens, buy some silicone caulk and seal up the hole just before you place the washer filter over the top below.

6) Slide the 1/4" OD clear tubing into the hole, and bring it and the bottle outside. Make sure you know approximately how much tubing you need to get from the bottom of the bottle (where the bottle cap is) to wherever you want the water. Mark the tubing, then cut it to length.

7) With the tube cut to the appropriate length, slide the tube back into the hole in the bottle cap (not connected to the bottle during this step), and slide one of the plastic sleeves around the tube. I'm not sure if this does anything, but maybe it does? Makes the tube bigger so it won't fall through the hole? Once you perform the next step below, the plastic sleeve will be held in place by friction, as will the tube itself.

8) It may take a lot of pressure (I used oil on the metal insert, and it worked much easier with that), but insert the metal insert into the tube as shown in the photos. You don't want a lot of tube hanging out of the end of the bottle cap. Just enough that the sleeve is inside the bottle cap, and the insert is halfway in, halfway out of the cap. You need enough room, also, to fit the hose washer with screen over the top below.

9) Place the hose washer with screen over the top of the tube/metal insert. It's okay if it's right up against the metal. It's important that you press the rubber part of the washer as far into the bottle cap as possible. You may need to "shave" a little of the rubber off, if the bottle cap won't seal onto the bottle enough to provide a tight seal.

10) Screw the bottle cap onto the bottle. It should go about halfway. If it's not securing properly, your washer may be too thick. This is easy to correct: either buy a thinner screen washer, or trim away a little of the outside of the washer, so that part is thinner, and interferes less with the closing of the bottle cap. It should be snug, but secure.

11) Install a push-fit shut-off valve on the other end of the tube. Close the valve. I didn't close the valve, and when I went to fill it, I kept wondering why it was taking so long to fill. Close the valve! :)

12) With the bottle assembly complete, install the bottle assembly on the support structure, with the tube hanging down below the bottom of the support, as shown in the pictures.

13) I like to secure the tube so that the valve is close to the plant. You can also place additional tubing on the opposite end of the valve, so that it goes: bottle, tube, valve, tube. The last part of the tube would be what is close to the plant.

14) The holes you drilled in the top (bottom?) of the bottle are big, and will let all sorts of tube and filter clogging goodness in. The plastic cover/sieve should help you keep bigger pieces out, which is good. Just rinse the sieve or maybe just brush it off, and you're good. This isn't drinking water, so it doesn't need to be clean, just keep the chunks and leaves off.

15) Now it's time to fill the water bottle from the top (bottom?), after placing the plastic sieve on the top. Just grab some water from your favorite water source, and pour it into the top/sieve as fast as the holes will allow. If you were smart and made sure the valve was closed earlier, you should eventually have a filled water bottle. Check for leaks. Leaks should be semi-obvious. It's not a big deal if you have leaks - you'll just want to seal them up with caulk or, perhaps, by tweaking the bottle-cap area, where most leaks are going to happen.

16) Test the system by turning on the valve, and watching the water flow. Once the plant is watered, which should be within a few seconds of flow, turn the valve fully off.

17) Secure the valve/tubing in such a way that the water drips/pours out as close to the base of the plant as possible. This is where the plant comes up out of the ground, and is the best place to water, as this water should go directly to the roots. If your plant is weird, and has roots elsewhere, consult your resident green thumb. I am not a green thumb. You could ask me, which is fine, but Google knows more than I do!

18) Stand back and have a beverage of choice. Barring any leaks, you now have a completely manual drip irrigation system with a 1.5L reservoir. It may fill when it rains, but I don't know yet. The next revision is probably going to integrate some sort of surface area maximization...thing. If you have any ideas for maximizing surface area (that's what SHE said!) please let me know.

Parts List

Water Bottle: Trader Joe's Alkaline Water + Electrolytes 1.5L - SKU: 53530
Shut Off Valve: John Guest, PPSV040808WD - SKU 759472 (PL-3011)
Sleeves & Inserts: Compression - 1/4 in OD: Everbilt - SKU 537 020 (A-8)
Hose Washer with Screen: Danco - SKU 80070
Wood Screws: Everbilt, #6 x 1/2 in, Flat Head Phillips, Brass - SKU 252 573

Got everything at Home Depot, but I'm sure Lowe's or whatever other hardware store you like or have locally will have these things, or equivalent. I designed this with common/popular tools and items. If you can recommend something that's better, please leave me details in the comments. I like to improve my design and directions!

Also, if you have a water bottle that differs from this bottle, please give me the specs in a comment, and I'll try to redesign a different set of STL files for your application. Hopefully we can get a good set of popular bottles so we can reduce the number of items that go to the landfill or recycling center. Reuse is better than recycling!

As promised, here are the specs for the bottle I used:

Bottle diameter: 87 mm
Bottle "neck" diameter: 26 mm
End of bottle "neck" diameter: 33 mm
Neck to Top of Bottle Cap: 22 mm
Height of bottle: impossible to measure with my calipers, therefore, impossible to measure.

Okay, fine, it's 0.0003048 km from bottom of bottle to top of bottle-cap.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

Fusion 360 is my friend. It allowed me to quickly design this system from idea, to digital, to reality within a week or so. It took me time, and a lot of sketching in a drawing program to figure out exactly what I had, and what I wanted, but in the end, it was fairly easy to create, and I attribute some of that to my computer skill, and some of that to the ever-improving interface and features of Fusion 360. Thank you, Autodesk!

Simplify3D is another awesome program, which lets me slice, optimize and print my prints. It does a very good job.

comments.text: Very cool ideas. Nice compilation indeed.
comments.author: dcadot

comments.text: Doesn't PLA degrade in rain?
comments.author: ForAiur

comments.text: Yes, but it's less of a structural thing, and more of a cosmetic thing.  I was also concerned, and watched a bunch of videos where people made garden-related items out of PLA, and the main concern after a year or more was color fading and possibly some brittleness. When I screwed the supports into the fence, I ended up putting too much pressure on the plastic (by screwing it in too tight), and with the 30/40% in-fill, it eventually broke. I think you'd want to either A) print with a higher in-fill and/or B) not screw the screws in too tight, or possibly use a soft rubber washer?  I think with this design, I needed to make the wings go out longer (left and right), so there's more support for the screws.  I'm starting to think a better design might be a taller "wing" that is deeper (for more strength).  I like to design and print my items with as few supports as possible - support-free if I can swing it - so I really just need to make the screw hole "wings" go out a little more, and maybe a little deeper. We'll see!

I am a fond user of the Scottoiler eSystem, an automated system to lubricate your motorcycle's chain & sprockets.

However, mine was installed on the left handlebar, using the standard mounting bracket. This works good normally, but alas - not in combination with my tank bag! In tight turns, when moving the bike about, the display unit often hit into the bag... Not the best base for a long product life, I thought...

So I figured, I'd try to think of an alternative mounting assembly & here's my take. :-)

The platform (for the display) and the clamps for the handlebar were easily done - for the swivel, I needed a few iterations to find the one that (I think) will suit my bike best.

  • 1) This design is intended for a Suzuki V-Strom: other bikes may have different handlebar diameters.
  • 2) The handlebar clamp #2 is fitted with a thin neoprene rubber sheet, to increase friction on the handlebar.
  • 3) Tolerances are targetted at my printer & settings - adjust as required.
  • 4) I figured, the #3 swivel will suit my bike best: I included the other 2 versions in case someone might find these useful.
  • 5) Parts are configured for metric bolts & nuts - adjust as required.

You'll find the STEP source files included, to allow any of the above mentioned changes, should these be required.

The printed parts are freshly painted, so I can't add an "as-mounted" picture just yet: will update later. ==> Added 22nd Aug. :-)

description.text:
Here is a simple thing for all of you, who love their Magic Mice! ;)
This box keeps away scratches and dust from the Magic Mouse when you carry it in a bag.

I know, the quality of the print on the photos is very poor - it was a very "quick and dirty" print. Both stl files I uploaded are finer faceted than the ones I used for this print.

The layer adhesion have to be really good to get durable hooks. If the hooks break, you can hold the box together with a simple rubber band.

Just put some type of foam material into the cover. This presses down the mouse gently to the bottom to avoid moving inside the box while transportation.

Please take a look at my open-source tool which can help you to manage your 3DP projects easily:

title: MINI Cooper Key Fob Trim Ring

description.text:
My wife wanted a different color trim ring for her MINI Cooper key, so I went into Fusion 360 and came up with this! Now you can add some color to your key fob. Print one in your favorite color, or one to match the color of your car.

Disclaimer: They do not grip the key fob as tightly as the original. You may need to add a little adhesive to keep it secured (would NOT recommend super glue, unless you want it to be permanent). I have not added any adhesive and after a few days of use, it hasn't fallen off.

Update: I experimented with a bit of glue stick mixed with hairspray (that's all I had on hand other than super glue) to create a paste to smear on the inner part of the trim ring in hopes of securing it in place a bit better. Worked out great after the mixture dried. It's holds firmly enough that it doesn't fall off, but also isn't such a strong bond that it won't ever come off.

Notes:

Best results when printed with .2mm layer height or lower. I would also recommend a .4mm nozzle or smaller. At the thinnest point of the model, the walls are .4mm thick.

The ones pictured are printed at .1mm layer heights with an initial layer height of .2mm with a .4mm nozzle.

title: Bottle rocket launch pad and nozzle

description.text:
WARNING!! You use this at your own risk! Structural integrity of 3D printed parts is hard to predict so use this with caution and wear protective gear (especially safety glasses) to protect yourself from debris should any of the parts fail.

Update 30/06/2017 Added a thread-less version of the nozzle in STEP format so you can make your own threads if you have a different bottle type. The cavity is 30mm wide and 13mm deep at the outer edges (there is a 2mm chamfer in the bottom so at the nozze it is 15mm deep.

Update 28/6/2017 Forgot to add the base structure (called housing)! :D sorry, now it's added!

This is a really improvised experiment to create a fun water rocket launch pad and nozzle. I wanted to use the compressor or a bike wheel pump without gardena connectors.

The release mechanism uses a rotating "locking ring" where you can connect a line for remote triggering. The system only works with the attached nozzle.

To build the air pressure connector, cut of the air valve from an old deflated bike tyre. I use the type with a car tyre valve for ease of use.

The water connector has a restriction valve to block air pressure from going into the water hose but I haven't tried this one yet as my prototype didn't work and I have changed it to the version that is now online.

The base has 3 "arms", one for air pressure, one for water supply and the third is prepared for whatever use might arise, why not connect your soda stream CO2 bottle? or I don't know. :) just drill out the hole in the middle and add your creation. There is already a channel inside so you only need to drill around a cm.

The system uses a number of different O-rings, I bought a box of different sizes and I'm not 100% sure which is the best everywhere so I suggest you buy a bunch of different sizes and try. The one between the base and the nozzle is the most critical and it depends on how much pressure you are going to use, which one will fit. To tight = no liftoff.

Regarding fins The nozzle has fastening with 3mm wide gap for fins. This is to allow a sheet of depron or similar material to use as fins. I did not include STL for fins as the shape of the ones in the picture is totally wrong, they are too small and do not make the rocket fly straight. You can try to make fins of different designs and see what works best and make sure they are not too strong, the idea is that the fins should break before the attachment in the nozzle. If you have fins made from a strong material, use for example a wood pin to lock it in place.

This is highly experimental, but I decided to release it once I got the prototype working and it does for air pressure, the water connector is in progress. You have to attach an external valve to control the water flow. The principal should be to first fill water, then air pressure, then pull the line to release.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print nozzle and connectors with 100% infill if you use PLA. When I printed the first prototype housing I used 20% infill and 6 perimeters and 0,35mm layer height to make a quick print, this did not work, the housing was not air tight!! When I print the next prototype I will use more perimeters and 0,2mm layer heights. I have also made the water channel narrower to make it easier to get it tight.
All improvised using Fusion 360, made to resemble full scale rocket motor nozzle and a futuristic launch pad.

comments.text: I'm soon ready for launch with this design. I must say that I am impressed by the mechanics.

comments.author: pgrunwald

comments.text: Hi! yes it is useful to the extent that I have tested air pressure by filling up the bottle first under the tap (to about 3'd) with water and then placing it on the launch pad, then pressurize it from a compressor and release with a string attached to the locker ring. This far I can say for sure works. What I haven't tested is the water connector as I didn't have time to complete it before I went to the country house to test it. Also, my prototype leaked pretty much so I had to fill fill the water end of it with melt glue to get it pressure tight. I guess I was printing it too fast with too thick layers (0,35mm, the fast profile in Slic3r) so the layers wasn't bonded 100% leaving lots of small gaps. I used 6 perimeters and 20% infill, and I think that is OK if you print with 0,2 or 0,25mm layers and not too fast so that you get even and well bonded layers. What you can do if you only want to use the air pressure connector is make a plate with 4 holes and just plug the water end for now.

title: Moto G5 PLUS protective case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This case is designed for the Motorola (Lenovo) Moto G5. It has two cutouts on the back, for the camera bump and for the Motorola logo. On the side, it has a cutout for the volume key buttons and lock button and, on the bottom, it has a cutout for the charging port and the audio jack. If printed properly, it should snap nicely in, like a normal commercial case.

NOTICE: Unlike what you see on the photos, the 3D model has also a cutout on the back for the noise canceling microphone. I noticed the mistake only after printing the first case. I will update the post with new pictures soon.

UPDATE!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Please note that this case is for the G5 Plus, NOT for the G5. Sorry for my error.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Preferably, print it with soft, flexible materials like ABS, PETG, TPU or BDP (as the one in the pictures). You can also try PLA, but you might break it when trying to squeeze the phone in and out of the case.

Use the mouse-ears model for materials with warping potential. Cut them away with a cutter-knife after you remove the print from the build platform.

I designed it based on my personal measurements of the Moto G5 and I would estimate an average measurement error of ca. 0.5 mm (on the corner fillets). Still, all the cutouts seem to allign perfectly and it clips really nicely around the phone.

The case is designed to be squeezed over the phone like regular, commercial cases.

The pattern on the back draws inspiration from 3D-like patterns, usually associated with 3D printing... and it looks COOL!

Also, a really great advantage is that the phone sits much nicer in the hand and is not as slippery as without the case... so, with this one, you get both prevention and protection;)

description.text:
Want to know the best configuration ?
Choose a different process for each of the models and change everything
For ex : speed ,layer height, temperature, layer with, etc.
Than exemine the cubes and you will know which one is the best.
